Travels in Asia and Africa 1325-1354
The Travels of Ibn Battuta A.D. 1325-1354

Born in Tangier in 1304, Ibn Battuta traveled from North Africa to the Middle East, where he performed the hajj, and on to Turkey, Iran, and through central Asia to China. He is estimated to have covered some 75,000 miles between 1324 and 1354 and left the world a remarkable account of his adventures in the medieval world

title: Book of Travels

Though this book was written before the age of the Mongols, I am including it because it gives a vivid picture of the Medieval Islamic world into which the Mongols irrupted. In fact Nasir-i-Khusraw lived at the time of the first great irruption of Turks, the Saljuqs, into the Islamic world, and historians frequently compare and contrast the coming of the Saljuq Turks and the Mongols nearly two hundred years later

imperiale des sciences. The Orbelian family were Armenian nobles who established close relations with the Mongols and were loyal servants of the Il-Khans. A modern translation but a beautifully and lavishly
of the travels of Marco Polo are available in varying degrees of erudition including the Everyman Edition
In addition, the travels are available online in extracts and in their entirety. Marco Polo remains one of the most important sources for the Mongols and the Yiian dynasty
Karnameh-ye Awqaf
Mongol Ode" and "Pur-i-Baha' and his Poems

Pur-i-Baha' was a satirical poet during the time that the Juwayni family was at the height of its power in thirteenth-century Iran. The fact that Pur-i-Baha' felt free to write such biting satire against the government of the time is indicative of the freedom of expression which prevailed in Ilkhanid Iran

note: Other translations of his poetry appear in E.G. Browne's Literary History of Persia.
title: His most famous poem, the Mongol Ode, demonstrates just how many Mongolian and Turkish idioms, phrases, and words were in current usage in the Persian of the thirteenth century

container-title: It provides details of Hulegu's wives and sons and of his establishment of the Il-Khanate, up until his death in 1265
title: Histoire des Mongols de la Perse
This is a French translation, extremely well annotated, of Rashid al-DIn's history of Hulegu, taken from the Compendium of Chronicles

note: Another scholarly translation from Rashid al-DIn's Compendium of Chronicles, this section covers the rule of the Great Khans until Temiir Qa'an (d. 1307).
title: The Successors of Genghis Khan

note: This is by far the most important translated text for the study of the Mongols.
title: Rashiduddin Fazlullah Jami 'u' t-Tawarikh: Compendium of Chronicles

& Literature 45, Central Asian Sources, Harvard University. Thackston's translation of the great statesman and historian Rashid al-DIn's epic Compendium of Chronicles is an admirable achievement. This work is considered the world's first universal history. Rashid al-DIn was able to draw on a great variety of sources both Eastern and Western, and he had the full cooperation of the Mongol courts in his endeavors
Tehran: Nashr albaraz. This is the latest four-volume edition of this important work. It contains two volumes of indexes, glossaries, notes, and black and white illustrations

note: Facsimile edition with some wonderful illustrations.
title: Tanksuq-nameh yd tibb ahl-i-Khitd

publisher: Institute for Humanities and Cultural Studies
title: Matla' al-Sa'dayn
Legends of the Sufis: Selections from Menaqibu' I'Arifin, trans, and preface by Idries Shah, Shams al-Din Ahmad, el-Eflaki
Aflaki was a follower of the Sufi order founded by Rumi. These stories, both mythical and factual, provide valuable information about the life and teaching of the great Sufi poet Jalal al-DIn Rumi

note: These are selected translations from the Arabic and provide a view of the events in western Asia and of the Mongols from an Egyptian, Mamluk perspective.
title: Selected Poems from the Divdn-i-Shams-i-Tabriz
This is a literal translation with accompanying Persian text. For lovers of Rumi this is an indispensable volume
Ayyubids, Mamlukes, and Crusaders: Selections from Tarikh al-Duwal wa'l-Muluk

note: is also available.
title: The Discourses of Rumi
This is a translation of Rumi's speeches and public addresses, including his views on his Mongol masters. A new translation by Wheeler Thackston, Signs of the Unseen

note: would be more suited to the nonspecialist reader.
title: The Mathnawi
This is Rumi's greatest work and various translations are available. It is a literal translation and more suited to the Persian speaker
Morals Pointed and Tales Adorned: The Bustan of Sa'di

Sa'di wrote for the Salghurid rulers of Shiraz. The Salghurids were for the main part faithful servants of their Mongol masters. Sa'di's words of wisdom and advice reflect the society and customs of his time but also have a timeless relevance quite applicable to modern times
Majma' al'ansdb

note: These are crusader chronicles, but they cover the period of Mongol engagement.

Histoire des Tartars

note: Smpad had firsthand knowledge of the Mongols, the court in Mongolia, and the Il-Khans.
title: The Armenian Chronicles of Constable Smpad, or The Royal Historian

Dumbarton Oaks Papers 13:141-68. Constable Smpad (1208-76) was a high-ranking official at the Armenian court of Cilicia and brother of King Het'um. The Armenians of Cilicia made a pact with the Mongols in the 1240s and became allies

The Vinland Map and the Tartar Relation. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press. This account of the Franciscans' journey to the Mongol court was written by a member of Carpini's party. It contains additional details and facts not found in Carpini's version of the journey
Tasawwurat or Rawdatu't-Taslim
Another example of Tusi's philosophical and religious works
The Longer Introduction to the Zij al-Ilkhani of Nasir-al-Din Tusi
Journal of Semitic Studies 8. This is a technical piece of work written for Hulegu by Tusi
Nasir al-DIn on Finance
The Nasirean Ethics
This is Tusi's most famous work. It is in the tradition of Mirror for Princes and gives moral and political advice to rulers
The Death of the Last Abbasid Caliph: A Contemporary Muslim Account

note: In the Persian editions of Juwaynl's history, Tusi's amendment is usually included.
title: The Mongol World Empire 1206-1370
Tusi wrote this account of the destruction of Baghdad, an event in which he played a leading role, and amended it to Juwaynl's History of the World Conqueror

container-title: It was for Tusi that Hulegu built the observatory and library, the Rasadkhaneh, in Maragheh, northwestern Iran, in about 1260
title: Contemplation and Action: The Spiritual Autobiography of a Muslim Scholar
London: Tauris and The Institute of Isma'ili Studies. This is the spiritual autobiography of Tusi, who became a close adviser to Hulegu

note: d. 1282). Vardan was particularly close to Hulegu's wife, Dokuz Khatun.
title: The Historical Compilation of Vardan Arewelc'i
The Armenian cleric wrote this general history, which continues to the reign of Abaqa Khan

note: This is now available online.
title: The Monks of Kublai Khan, Emperor of China. London: Religious Tract Society. This is the account of the embassy of the Nestorian (eastern Christian) patriarch, Yaballaha III, and his vicar, Bar Sauma, from Qubilai Khan to the courts of Europe at the end of the thirteenth century
Tdrikh-i Wassaf

note: The story is recounted by the holy man's disciple, Li Chih Ch'ang, and provides important insights into the personality of Chinggis Khan.
title: The Travels of an Alchemist

This account of Chinggis Khan's spiritual advisor, who accompanied the Great Khan in his final years, has recently been republished. It is an account of the travels of Ch'ang Ch'un, summoned to central Asia by the Great Khan, whom he then accompanied southward across Afghanistan into Sind and then back again to central Asia

container-title: and trans., The Journey of William of Rubruck to the Eastern Parts of the World, 1253-55, as Narrated by Himself, with Two Accounts of the Earlier Journey of John of Plan de Carpine
note: available at:
title: The Mission of Friar William of Rubruck, trans

This account of the journey of the Franciscan missionary, William of Rubruck, to the court of Mongke Khan is an invaluable source of information and descriptions of the Mongols and the lands under their domination. Quotations used in the present text are taken from W
Land behind Baghdad

This is a description of Baghdad and its hinterland during the decades before the Mongol invasion that demonstrates that the decline in this city's fortunes had begun long before the arrival of Hulegu

Mongol Imperialism: The Policies of the Grand Qan Mongke 1251-1259. Los Angeles: University of California Press. This is an important analysis of the split in the Mongol ruling family and the development of the Tuluids under Mongke
Mongolian Princes and Their Merchant Partners 1200-1260
Allsen investigates the relationship between merchants and their royal financial backers and demonstrates the close links between the Mongols and international commerce
Commodity and Exchange in the Mongol Empire: A Cultural History of Islamic Textiles
This important study shows the crucial role that precious fabrics, and gold cloth in particular, played in the expansion and development of the Mongol Empire

note: He demonstrates just how involved the Mongols became in the
title: Culture and Conquest in Mongol Eurasia
Allsen's study of Iran and China focuses on the roles of the Mongol Yiian official Bolad Aqa and the Persian Il-Khanid minister Rashid al-DIn

container-title: Bulletin of the School of Oriental & African Studies
title: ment A new book excites those ripples to tidal proportions
Culture and Conquest in Mongol Eurasia

note: Khazanov, Manz, and others.
title: Mongols, Turks, and Others: Eurasian Nomads and the Sedentary World
This is an excellent collection of articles from many of the big names in the world of Mongol studies, including Morgan
Mongols and Mamluks: The Mamluk-Ilkhanid War 1260-1281
Amitai-Preiss gives a detailed breakdown of the wars between the Mamluks of Egypt, who stopped the Mongols' conquest of the whole Islamic world, and the Il-Khanids, or Mongols, of Iran
The Conversion of Teglider Ilkhan to Islam

Jerusalem Studies in Arabic and Islam 25:15-43. Tegudar was the first of the Iranian Mongols to convert to Islam, although the rest of his court did not follow his example. This is a very interesting and informative study of Tegudar's short reign
Hulegu and the Ayyubid Lord of Transjordan

container-title: Journal of Economic and Social History of the Orient
title: Sufis and Shamans

container-title: Bulletin of the Asian Institute ofPahlavi University
title: Two Aspects of Iranian Buddhism
The Imamzadeh Ma'sum at Vardjovi: A Rock-cut Il-Khanid Complex Near Maragheh

author.literal: Barthold, V. V., trans., and T. Minorsky.

title: Turkestan down to the Mongol Invasion

This study is a classic and explores in depth the historical development of the Turkish steppe people and Central Asia. Its central subject is the land of Turkestan before and after the Mongol invasions

note: Available at:
title: The Turco-Mongol Invasions and the Lords of Armenia in the 13th-14th Centuries. Long Branch, N.J.: Sources of the Armenian Tradition

Robert Bedrosian has made his doctoral dissertation available on the Internet as well as in hard copy and provides the most welcome translation of the medieval Armenian sources. His dissertation contains many translations of sources unavailable elsewhere

note: With the publication of this scholarly study, the Qara Khitai should enter the consciousness of the more general reading public.
title: The Empire of the Qara Khitai in Eurasian History

This extremely important book is the definitive account of the precursors of the Mongols, the Qara Khitai. It has sometimes been said that the coming of the Qara Khitai from Northern China to Central Asia circa 1125-30 was the first Mongol invasion. It differed from the invasion of the Chinggisids in that it was relatively peaceful and that Secondary Sources: Annotated Bibliography 299 the Qara Khitai established strong and peaceful relations with the Muslims of the region
A Fight between the Mongols: The Battle of Herat
Jerusalem: Institute of Advanced Studies, Hebrew University of Jerusalem. This short paper is an excellent model for students interested in probing deeper into the details of Mongol history
Qaidu and the Rise of the Independent Mongol State in Central Asia

A useful and readable portrait of a littleknown figure and an analysis of an under-studied area of Mongol history, Michal Biran's book would be welcomed by students wanting new, relatively untouched territory to further their studies

note: and they even tried to recruit their fellow Christians in Europe and in Palestine to join them.
title: The Cilician Kingdom of Armenia
The Armenians of Cilicia were early and willing allies of the approaching Mongols. The Armenians are a good example of a small kingdom that opted to cooperate rather than oppose the invaders
The New Islamic Dynasties
This reference book is a must for any student interested in Islamic political history

publisher: Department of Semitic Studies, University of Melbourne
title: The Monastry-church of Bar Hebraeus at Maragheh in West Azerbaijan
The Cambridge History of Iran
This work contains the standard studies of the Mongol period in Western Asia
The Mongol World Empire 1206-1370

This book collects various papers of the late John Boyle from Manchester University and covers all aspects of Mongol society and politics. Boyle is most famous for his linguistic expertise and his translations from various Asian languages
A Literary History of Persia
From Firdawsi to Sacdi

note: Browne has put together an excellent collection of translations and extracts from a wide variety of sources. These books have recently been reprinted.
title: A Literary History of Persia
Persian Literature under Tartar Domination 1265-1502

Both of these volumes by Browne, two from a four-volume work, provide a wonderful introduction to the Mongol period. Though no Mongol apologist, Browne gives an entirely different perspective on the Mongol period in his translations from the Persian. At one stage, Persian was almost the lingua franca of the Mongol Empire, and Iranians held important positions in administration, commerce, and cultural life throughout the empire
Persian Sufi Poetry: An Introduction to the Mystical Use of Classical Poems
The Mongol period saw an upsurge in the popularity of Sufism in western Asia, central Asia, and beyond. For those interested in this aspect of Mongol rule, this book is a valuable introduction

note: Another contribution to the study of this medieval sect.
title: Secondary Sources: Annotated Bibliography Burman, Edward
The Assassins: Holy Killers of Islam
Pre-Ottoman Turkey

note: The second book concentrates more on the Mongol period.
title: The Formation of Turkey, trans
Holt
These two books by Cahen provide a vivid picture of Anatolia (Turkey) before the coming of the Ottomans
The Devil's Horsemen

This classic is a very readable study of the Mongol invasion of Eastern Europe and Russia. It paints a vivid picture of the early Mongol invaders and gives a balanced account of their impact on Russia and its neighbors. This is an excellent introduction to the history of the Mongols
Trade and Civilisation in the Indian Ocean: An Economic History from the Rise of Islam to 1750
Trade in the Indian Ocean is often seen as peripheral to the study of the Mongols. This study proves otherwise and puts the events of the thirteenth century into context

note: A detailed study of Mongol law as practiced under the Yiian administration.
title: Chinese Legal Tradition under the Mongols: The Code of 1291 as Reconstructed
Western and Central Asians in China under the Mongols, trans, and annotated by Ch'ien Hsing-hai
The Yiian dynasty attracted visitors from Europe and western Asia to its fabulous courts. This is a book written from a Chinese perspective
A Medical Practice of the Mongols in the Thirteenth Century

Imperial Mongolian Cooking: Recipes from the kingdoms of Genghis Khan. New York: Hippocrene Books. This little book contains a wide range of dishes from the four main ulus of the Mongol Empire. The recipes have been adapted to modern times so the ingredients should all be easily accessible

note: This is an interesting and thought-provoking study of Tusi.
title: The Philosopher/Vizier: Khwaja Nasir al-DIn Tusi and the Isma c ills
Mediaeval Ismdcili History and Thought

note: Daftary has written the definitive study of this Muslim sect.
title: The Ismdcilis: Their History and Doctrines

The Assassin Legends: The Myths of the Ismdcilis. London: Taurus. Daftary's study clears up many of the misconceptions and myths about the medieval IsmacIlis. He explains why they became known as the Assassins

Islamization and Native Religion in the Golden Horde. University Park: Pennsylvania State University Press. This book is interesting for its study of the process of Islamization and its research into the nature of religion in the Golden Horde
Surviving the Mongols

This is an interesting account of the survival of the Ismaili Secondary Sources: Annotated Bibliography 301 community in Mongol-ruled Iran. Though it is rather cliched and dated in its portrayal of the Mongols, the book contains some valuable insights into life in Mongol Iran and how the secretive Ismaili community managed to survive and prosper against considerable odds

note: For serious students of the Mongols in China, Endicott-West is indispensable.
title: Imperial Governance in Yiian Times

note: The Jews were far more active and influential in western Asia during the medieval period than they are given credit for.
title: Jews in the Economic and Political Life of Mediaeval Islam
The Mongols: Ecological and Social Perspectives

This paper has now become an oftquoted classic. Lucidly and simply explained, it puts the Mongols in historical, political, and even anthropological context. This is a must for all students of the Mongols
Ecumenical mischief under the Mongols

container-title: Louvain: Secretariat du Corpus SCO . 1975, "Iconographie Syriaque Hulagu, Doquz Khatun . . . six Ambons," Le Museon 88
title: Chrdiens Syriaques sous les Mongols

container-title: In this book he discusses the question of legitimacy
publisher: Verlag der Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften. Herbert Frank
title: From Tribal Chieftain to Universal Emperor and God: The Legitimation of the Yiian Dynasty
has written widely on the Mongols and is a recognized expert
The Conquest of Armenia by the Mongol Armies
The First Armeno-Mongol Negotiations
These studies examine the relationship of both the Caucasian and Cilician Armenians with the Mongols
Levi-Provencal
The Encyclopaedia of Islam
This is a comprehensive and useful reference work
Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
An Introduction to the History of the Turkic Peoples

note: The Variorum collection includes some key papers on the people from the steppe.
title: Nomads and Their Neighbours in the Russian Steppe
Peter Golden's book is an excellent starting point for students embarking on the study of the Turkic and steppe peoples of central Asia
The Empire of the Steppes
This book has become a modern classic and puts the Mongol years into the perspective of steppe empires
Searches for an Imaginary Kingdom: The Legend of the Kingdom of Prester John
An unusual work but full of valuable research and insights
Russia in the Mongol Empire in Comparative Perspective
This article examines the Mongol conquests from a Russian point of view
The Tatar Yoke
Halperin examines the reasons behind the reluctance of Russian writers to deal with the Mongol domination of Russia

container-title: Bulletin of the School of Oriental & African Studies
title: The Kipchak Connection: The Ilkhans, the Mamluks and Ayn Jalut
This is a survey of events to the south in Iran and Syria from the view of the Golden Horde
Genghis Khan: Conqueror of the World

note: His book on Chinggis Khan is thoroughly researched, very readable, and clearly presented.
title: Russia and the Mongol Yoke: The History of the Russian Principalities and the Golden Horde, 1221-1502
Taurus. De Hartog has written two very readable accounts, though the second study takes the traditional Russian view of the Mongol years

container-title: The collection includes such articles as Joseph de Somogyi's 1933 translation and analysis of an Arabic poem written as a reaction to the destruction of Baghdad
title: Muslims, Mongols, and Crusades
This is a useful collection of articles published by SOAS [School of Oriental and African Studies], part of the University of London, which is concerned with the Mongols
The Religions of Mongolia
This book provides an excellent general background of religion and the medieval Mongols

note: Colin Heywood out-
title: Filling the Black Hole?: the Emergence of the Bithynian Atamanates 1298-1304
Howorth is an excellent introduction to history based directly on primary source material

note: This is the Mongols as seen from an Arab perspective.
publisher: State University of New York Press
title: From Saladin to the Mongols
Painting and Culture of the Mongols
This book contains a large collection of little-known artworks from the Mongol era that often depict the daily life of ordinary Mongols
The Middle East in the Middle Ages: The Early Mamluk Sultanate 1250-1382

note: His chapter on Timurlane in the Time-Life book is included with other pieces concerned with the Mongol conquests.
title: The Age of Calamity A.D
Amsterdam: Time-Life Books. Robert Irwin's study of the Mamluks presents the Arab world at the time of the Mongols
The Dissolution of the Mongol Empire
The State of Research: The Mongol Empire, 1986-1999
The Mongols and the West, 1221-1410

Peter Jackson's study of the breakup of the Mongol Empire is already a classic and the basis of most other studies and research on this subject. His work cannot be ignored. Jackson's latest book retains his distinctive eye for detail and exhaustive investigation and will become an indispensable volume in any library of the Mongols
A Change in Dynasties: Eoyalism in Thirteenth-Century China
Jennifer Jay studies the Sung Chinese loyalists and their attempts to resist cooperating with the Mongol Yiian dynasty
God's Unruly Friends. Salt Lake City: University of Utah Press. A detailed and scholarly study of the wandering dervishes, qalandars, and other eccentrics who populated medieval Persia

note: The collection includes work by Peter Golden, Reuven Amitai-Preiss, and Thomas Allsen.
title: Nomads and the Outside World
This is a collection of essays and papers concerned with Mongol society and its interaction with its sedentary neighbors
A Mediaeval Muslim Scholar at Work: Ibn Tawwus and his Library

The Eegacy of Genghis Khan: Courtly Art and Culture in Western Asia 1256-1353. New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. This long-overdue contribution to the field of Mongol studies is a lavishly illustrated book, rich in writing as well as pictures, that makes the case for a serious reassessment of the Mongol epoch. It would be difficult to view the Mongols as barbarian invaders after viewing the wealth and diversity of their cultural contributions and their patronage of the artistic life of their subject peoples
The Seljuks of Anatolia. Their History and Culture According to Local Muslim Sources

note: Both of Koprulu's books include valuable information on Mongol influence in Anatolia.
title: Secondary Sources: Annotated Bibliography
Islam in Anatolia after the Turkish Invasion (Prolegomena
Peoples of Central Asia
A wide study of the cultural diversity of central Asia

container-title: Rulers from the Steppe: State Formation on the Eurasian Periphery
note: An interesting study of the Mongol successor state, the Golden Horde.
title: The Culture of the Golden Horde and the Problem of the 'Mongol Legacy'

note: The legendary Ann Lambton is an acknowledged authority on medieval Persia, and she was one of the first to look at the Mongol period in depth. Another classic study.
title: Continuity and Change in Medieval Persia: Aspects of Administrative, Economic, Social History in llth-14th Century Persia
An Account of Bar Hebraeus Abu al-Faraj and His Relations with the Mongols of Persia
Arghun Aqa: Mongol Bureaucrat?
Early Mongol Rule in Thirteenth Century Iran

note: His interest in China and other parts of the Mongol Empire is reflected in his more recent work, however.
title: Genghis Khan and Mongol Rule

George Lane's earlier works are primarily concerned with the Mongols in Iran and how this whole period was one of cultural, spiritual, and economic renewal rather than of confrontation, stagnation, and oppression, as it has been previously characterized. The picture is of Mongol rulers rather than Mongol conquerors

note: much of it based on primary sourcebooks.
title: The Lands of the Eastern Caliphate
This is a geographical survey of medieval Persia

note: Essential reading for students of the Mongols in western Asia.
title: The Assassins: A Radical Sect in Islam
Lewis has produced a small, concise, and very readable account of this widely misunderstood Muslim sect
The Jews of Islam
This is a study of a neglected area and includes information on the Jews and the Mongols

note: Subsequent scholarly studies have often agreed with him.
title: Islam in History: Ideas, Peoples, and Events in the Middle East
Included in this collection is Lewis' memorable paper on the Mongols in which he dares to suggest that Western scholarship has been perhaps more unkind and unfair to their memory than they deserve
Rumi: Past and Present, East and West

This is the definitive book on the Sufi poet Rumi and a comprehensive study that also allows insight into the medieval Mongol-dominated world of western Asia and beyond. This very readable book provides a view of this period of history from an angle different from the usual political analysis but is equally valid. The book also contains a very practical and comprehensive bibliographical survey
Beyond Faith and Infidelity. Sufi Series
A detailed study of the Sufis and poets of western Asia under Mongol domination

container-title: Iran: Journal of the British Institute of Persian Studies
note: This paper deals with the Mongols' approaches to the Europeans and the English monarchs, Edward I and II in particular.
title: The Relations between Edward I and Edward II of England and the Mongol Il-Khans of Persia
Genghis Khan: Life, Death, and Resurrection

An apologist for Chinggis Khan who provides a vivid picture of the land in which the Great Khan grew up. The author writes his book around his quest for the final burial place of Chinggis Khan, which remains a mystery at the close of the book

note: Unfortunately out of print, this book is well worth the effort of a search.
title: Storm from the East

This book accompanied a television series, with David Morgan as the academic advisor. The result is a beautifully illustrated, clearly presented, simply explained account of the Mongols' rise and rule

note: which suggests that the Mongols were far more integrated into the societies that they conquered than had been previously thought.
title: Changes in Chancellery Languages and Language Changes in General in the Middle East, with Particular Reference to Iran in the Arab and Mongol Periods
This is a thought-provoking paper that researches language change during the Mongol period

note: This book casts new light on the relationships between the Mongols and their subjects.
title: The Origins of the Safawids

The Safavids, who came to power in Iran in 1500, trace their roots and the founding of their so-called family to the Il-Khanid period when their eponymous founder Safi al-DIn was close to the Mongol royal family
Padeshah-i Islam: The Conversion of Sultan Ghazan Khan

container-title: Iran: Journal of the British Institute of Persian Studies
title: The Itineraries of Sultan Oljeitu: 1304-16

note: Charles Melville is an authority on the Mongols and the later Il-Khans in particular. His work is extremely important, and his paper on the conversion to Islam of Ghazan Khan is particularly interesting.
title: 'Sometimes by the Sword, Sometimes by the Dagger': The role of the Isma^lis in Mamluk-Mongol relations in the 8th/14th Century
Rhetoric and Politics in Afghan Traditional Storytelling

Among the various interviews, storytelling sessions, and other oral transmissions are references to the Mongols, suggesting that the memory of the Chinggisid era is still very much alive in Afghanistan

publisher: Publications of the University of Tehran
title: Iranica Twenty Articles
The Turks, Iran and the Caucasus in the Middle Ages

note: central Asia, and the Mongols, and his work is still highly regarded today.
title: Secondary Sources: Annotated Bibliography
Medieval Iran and Its Neighbours
onetime Russian ambassador to Ottoman Turkey and later scholar and lecturer at London University's School of Oriental and African Studies, has written widely and knowledgeably about Iran
Medieval Historical Writing in the Christian Worlds. London: School of Oriental and African Studies
The Mongols
Medieval Persia, 1040-1797
Rashid al-DIn and Gazan Khan

container-title: Harvard Middle Eastern and Islamic Review
title: Mongol or Persian: The Government of Il-Khan Iran

David Morgan is considered one of the foremost authorities on the Mongols, and his book The Mongols has been translated into many languages and has been reprinted many times. All his work is well worth reading, and The Mongols should be the constant companion of any student of the Mongols. His deceptively readable style should not obscure the solid academic content. His Medieval Persia, 1040-1797 contains a particularly useful and comprehensive bibliographical survey of primary and secondary source material relevant to the period
The Mongol Empire and Its Legacy
An important collection of papers by many of the leading experts on the Mongols
Mapping the Silk Road and Beyond
A valuable collection of medieval maps, covering the Silk Road east and west. Each map is accompanied by an insightful text
Kalka River 1223: Genghiz Khan's Mongols Invade Russia
This is a beautifully illustrated, detailed account of the historic Mongol campaign which opened up Europe to the storm from the East. It is well served by clear maps and diagrams
Badr al-Din Lulu Atabeg of Mosul 1211-1259
An interesting study of a Kurdish warlord who ruled during the Mongol period and who allied himself with Hulegu
Central Tibet and the Mongols: The Yiian-Sa-skya Period of Tibetan History
In the Service of the Khan: Eminent Personalities of the Early Mongol-Yuan Period 1200-1300
An excellent study of officials from the Yiian dynasty, many of whom have not been dealt with elsewhere
Genghis Khan: His Life and Legacy
For the serious student of the Mongols, Ratchnevsky's book is indispensable. He is meticulous in his attention to detail and in his scrutiny of the sources, especially where differences occur
The Herb: Hashish versus Mediaeval Muslim Society
Khubilai Khan
This is an excellent and indispensable study of the founder of the Yiian dynasty of China

container-title: Journal of Economic and Social History of the Orient
title: Fear of Gynarchy in an Age of Chaos: Kong Qi's Reflections on Life in South China under Mongol Rule
This study considers the impact of foreign rule on the indigenous culture and the dissolution of the existing world order into apparent chaos
History of the Mongols

note: Unfortunately, his studies of the Golden Horde and the Il-Khanate are available only in German.
title: History of the Muslim World: The Mongol Period
Bertold Spuler is considered among the foremost authorities on the Mongols, and his books are treasure troves of details and data
The Lion of Egypt: Sultan Baybars I and the Near East in the 13C

Baybars, the legendary leader of the Mamluks of Egypt, successfully kept the Mongols at bay and even challenged them in Anatolia. This is a thorough and informative study and essential reading for an understanding of Baybar's role in medieval western Asia
Genghis Khan and the Mongol Conquests, 1190-1400

note: All three books by Turnbull are recommended.
title: Mongol Warrior, 1200-1350
This entire series is excellent, and the artwork is accurate and detailed
The Mongols
The Mongols and Russia
This is still one of the most thorough studies of the Mongol period in Russian history and contributes greatly to our understanding of the dynamics of the Golden Horde
The Mongol Orders of Submission to European Powers, 1245-1255
It is interesting to contrast these early communiques from the Mongols to the European courts with their later, more conciliatory correspondences

note: This book can be usefully read alongside the works of Claude Cahen.
title: The Decline of Medieval Hellenism in Asia Minor and the Process of Islamization from 11th Century through 15th Century
This is a bold and searching book that traces the changes in Anatolia brought first by the Turkish invasions and then later by the Mongol invasions and the decline in Greek influence
Genghis Khan and the Making of the Modern World

Another apologist for Chinggis Khan, Weatherford writes an interesting book because he approaches his subject primarily not as a historian but as an anthropologist. A readable and challenging study of the Great Khan
Storm across Asia: Genghis Khan and the Mongols. The Mogul Expansion
A useful introduction to Chinggis Khan and his successors
